title: The macronuclear genome of anaerobic ciliate Entodinium caudatum reveals its biological features adapted to the distinct rumen environment
abstract: Entodinium caudatum is an anaerobic binucleated ciliate representing the most dominant protozoal species in the rumen. However, its biological features are largely unknown due to the inability to establish an axenic culture. In this study, we primally sequenced its macronucleus (MAC) genome to aid the understanding of its metabolism, physiology, ecology. We isolated the MAC of E. caudatum strain MZG-1 and sequenced the MAC genome using Illumina MiSeq, MinION, and PacBio RSII systems. De novo assembly of the MiSeq sequence reads followed with subsequent scaffolding with MinION and PacBio reads resulted in a draft MAC genome about 117 Mbp. A large number of carbohydrate-active enzymes were likely acquired through horizontal gene transfer. About 8.74% of the E. caudatum predicted proteome was predicted as proteases. The MAC genome of E. caudatum will help better understand its important roles in rumen carbohydrate metabolism, and interaction with other members of the rumen microbiome.

abstract.text: Entodinium caudatum is an anaerobic binucleated ciliate representing the most dominant protozoal species in the rumen. However, its biological features are largely unknown due to the inability to establish an axenic culture. In this study, we primally sequenced its macronucleus (MAC) genome to aid the understanding of its metabolism, physiology, ecology. We isolated the MAC of E. caudatum strain MZG-1 and sequenced the MAC genome using Illumina MiSeq, MinION, and PacBio RSII systems. De novo assembly of the MiSeq sequence reads followed with subsequent scaffolding with MinION and PacBio reads resulted in a draft MAC genome about 117 Mbp. A large number of carbohydrate-active enzymes were likely acquired through horizontal gene transfer. About 8.74% of the E. caudatum predicted proteome was predicted as proteases. The MAC genome of E. caudatum will help better understand its important roles in rumen carbohydrate metabolism, and interaction with other members of the rumen microbiome.

body_text.text: Rumen ciliates, which constitute the second largest group of the ruminal microbiota (based on the microbial biomass), are specifically adapted to the carbohydrates-and microbes-rich anaerobic environment only typical of the rumen and similar gut environments [1] . They play several important roles, including participating in feed digestion and fermentation, promoting methane production, lowering nitrogen utilization efficiency (NUE) by driving intraruminal recycling of microbial protein, and shaping the rumen microbiome by predation and other types of microbial interactions [2, 3] . Entodinium caudatum is the most researched 'model' species of rumen protozoa because of its dominance [4] and high bacterivorous activity, both of which make E. caudatum the most influential rumen ciliate [5] [6] [7] . However, the lack of and inability to establish any axenic cultures of any ruminal ciliate species have hindered the understanding of their physiological and ecological adaptation to the unique rumen environment. Thus, their actual roles in the rumen could only be inferred from indirect evidence [8] [9] [10] [11] .

Ciliates (e.g. Tetrahymena thermophila, Paramecium tetraurelia, and Oxytricha trifallax) have one micronucleus (MIC) and one macronucleus (MAC), with each having a discrete genome [12] . The MIC genome functions only during sexual reproduction to generate a MAC through programmed DNA rearrangements [13] , whereas the MAC genome determines non-reproductive metabolic functions during vegetative growth. Similar to free-living ciliates, symbiotic rumen ciliates also have nuclear dimorphism [14] . The MAC genomes of about 10 ciliate species, mostly model ciliates, have been sequenced, including T. thermophila [15] [16] [17] , P. tetraurelia [18] , P. caudatum [19] , Ichthyophthirius multifiliis [20] , and O. trifallax [21] . The MAC genomes and subsequent genomic studies have provided new knowledge that was otherwise impossible to gain, including several unique genetic features such as single-gene nanochromosomes, tiny introns [22] , and extensive genome fragmentation [21] . It is also intriguing that the MAC of the species of the classes Oligohymenophorea (i.e. T. thermophila and P. tetraurelia) and Heterotrichea (e.g. Stentor coeruleus) have relative "normal" eukaryotic MAC chromosomes, with each carrying ten to hundreds of genes [15, 23, 24] , while that of the species of the classes Phyllopharyngea (e.g. Chilodonella uncinata), Spirotrichea (e.g. O. trifallax, Stylonychia lemnae), and Armophorea (e.g. Nyctotherus ovalis) have tens of thousands of extremely short MAC nanochromosomes, some of which carry only one or a very few genes with flanking telomeres [21, 22, 25, 26] . All the species of rumen ciliates belong to the class Litostomatea within the phylum Ciliophora. No species of this class has had its genome sequenced until the present study. Here we report the E. caudatum MAC genome and some of the metabolic, physiological, and ecological features inferred from the MAC genome. This study advances understanding of the genomic and biological features of E. caudatum in particular, and ruminal ciliates in general.

The E. caudatum monoculture, which was initially isolated from the rumen of a Gerenuk [27] , has been maintained in our lab by daily feeding with ground wheat grain and alfalfa and grass hays and by regular transfer of the monoculture to an equal volume of fresh SP medium as described in our previous study [14] . The overall experimental and analysis procedures are shown in Fig. 1A . Briefly, cells of E. caudatum MZG-1 were isolated from an actively growing monoculture (in terms of rumen protozoa; approximately 15,000 to 20,000 cells per ml of monoculture and 150 ml was used per isolation) by removing the free-living and loosely associated prokaryotic cells by sequential filtrations and washing through three nylon filter membranes of decreasing pore sizes (50, 25 , and 10 μm) as described previously [28] . The washed E. caudatum cells (Fig. 1B) were verified using microscopy [28] and then resuspended in modified medium A that contained 4% (w/v) gum arabic, 0.1 M sucrose, 0.1% (w/v) spermidine-HCl, 2 mM MgCl 2 , 5 mM Tris, 0.5 mM EDTA, pH 6.75, 100 μM PMSF, and 0.63% (v/v) N-octyl alcohol [28, 29] . Macronuclei were isolated after lysing the E. caudatum cells using a physical (ultrasonic homogenization) and chemical method [29, 30] . Repeated size-exclusion using 10-μm filter membrane and sedimentation followed by removal of 95% of the supernatant contaminating prokaryotic cells and purified the MAC. Finally, Percoll gradient centrifugation was used for further purifying the isolated MAC according to the method described in Allen, 2000 [28] . The purified MAC were confirmed microscopically after staining with methyl green (Fig. 1C) . After additional washing, the purified MAC was resuspended in the modified medium A minus gum arabic, and the MAC DNA was extracted using a phenol/chloroform method modified from Aeschlimann et al. [26] and confirmed using PCR amplifying the ciliate actin gene (Fig. 1D ). The MAC DNA was sequenced using Illumina MiSeq to produce short (2 × 300 bp) reads and MinION and PacBIO RSII systems to produce long reads (average 10 kb, maximum 100 kb).
body_text.section: Macronuclear DNA isolation from E. caudatum monoculture and genomic library construction

body_text.text: We obtained ~80 million paired-end (2 × 300 bp) reads from two MiSeq sequencing runs. Trimmomatic (v. 3.2.2) trimmed off the Illumina adapters and filtered out the sequence reads with a Q score < 20 over a 4 bp window [31] . Reads <75 bp were removed, so were K-mers (k = 31) matching Univec or Emvec database sequences. The qualitychecked reads (74,093,890 reads in total) were then de novo assembled (referred to as MiSeq assembly) using SPAdes (v3.13.1) [32] . The long reads from the MinION and the PacBIO RS II were corrected using Porechop (v0.2.3, github.com/rrwick/Porechop) and LoRDEC (v0.8), respectively [33] . The short MiSeq reads and the error-corrected long MinION reads were used together for scaffolding using SSPACE Long-Read scaffolder (version 2.0) [34] , resulting in a hybrid assembly. The hybrid-assembly was further scaffolded with the error-corrected PacBIO long reads using SSPACE LongRead scaffolder, producing the tribrid assembly. The tribrid assembly was polished using Gapfiller (v2.1.1) and Pilon (v.1.23) with the short MiSeq reads as the input. Possible contaminations were identified and removed by the NCBI SRA database when the tribrid assembly was uploaded to the database.
body_text.section: Sequence clean up and MAC genome assembly

body_text.text: The 18S rRNA gene sequences (full length) of E. caudatum, Eu. vannus, I. multifiliis, O. trifallax, Ste. coeruleus, Sty. lemnae, and T. thermophila were used to construct a maximum parsimony phylogenetic tree using MEGA6 [35] . The most recent MAC genomic data of the other ciliate species available online at (ciliate.org) and in the relevant literature (see Supplementary Table S1 ) were used to calculate the MAC genome statistics. Assembly statistics and the number of genes in the E. caudatum MAC genome were evaluated using Quast (version 4.6.3) [36] and by manual search in the GFF (a standard file format for storing genomic features) files. The MAC genome and assembly statistics were compared between E. caudatum and the other ciliate species. The taxonomic distribution of the protein-coding genes of E. caudatum was compared with that of the other ciliate species using MG-RAST [37] .
body_text.section: Comparison with the MAC genomes of other ciliate species

body_text.text: Genes were predicted from the MAC genome using AUGUSTUS (version 3.2.2) [38] with the RNA-seq transcriptomic data [39] and the protein sequences of E. caudatum in the Swiss-Prot database (accessed in Jan. 2019) as hints. We performed ab initio gene prediction using the command-line procedures suggested by Hoff and Stanke [40] , including RNA-seq mapping, hints file generation, and training and optimization of AUGUSTUS with 1000 E. caudatum gene structures randomly selected from the RNA-seq data. The minimum intron length for AUGUSTUS training was adjusted from 39 to 15 bp as previously suggested for ciliates [41] . We use the following parameters in AUGUSTUS: --species=Entodinium --extrinsicCfgFile=extrinsic.M.P.RM.E.W.Entodinium.cfg --hintsfile=concatenated.hints.gff --allow_hinted_splicesites =atac --softmasking=on --genemodel=complete --codingseq=on. The protein sequences translated from the predicted genes using the universal genetic code as previously suggested [42, 43] were first annotated using Blast2GO [44, 45] and then InterProScan (database version 62) [46] . Further detailed annotations were performed against the COG database (ftp.ncbi.nih.gov/pub/COG/COG2014/data/) and the Swiss-Prot database (www.uniprot.org/downloads). Protein domains were annotated using the Pfam database (version 32.0) [47] with the profile hidden Markov model (HMM) (hmmer.org/) applied. The translated amino acid sequences were mapped to the KEGG metabolic pathway database using BlastKOALA (accessed on July 8, 2020) [48] . The rRNA genes were predicted using RNAmmer (version 1.2) [49] and Rfam (version 14.2) [50] . BLASTN search against the non-redundant NCBI nt database was used to confirm the putative rRNA genes.

To assess the draft MAC genome for completeness, we predicted the core eukaryotic genes (CEGs) and tRNA genes and estimated the mapping rate of DNA and assembled RNA-Seq sequences. We used a threestep approach to identify the CEGs. First, we performed BLAST search against the CEG dataset (korflab.ucdavis.edu/datasets/genome_completeness/). Second, using hmmscan (HMMER3 v.3.3; hmmer.org), we searched for the Pfam-A HMM profiles of CEGs to identify any CEGs that were not found in the previous BLAST search. When a gene had a Pfam domain assigned to CEGs with an E-value <1e-3, it was considered as a CEG. Third, we searched the eggNOG database (version 4.5) for the CEGs still missing after the first and second searches. The proportion of the CEGs predicted in the E. caudatum MAC genome was calculated against the CEG dataset (248 in total). The tRNA genes were predicted using the tRNAscan-SE (version 2.0.5) and Rfam (version 14.2) [50, 51] to determine if the tRNA genes for all the amino acids of cellular organisms had been accounted for.
body_text.section: Evaluation of MAC genome completeness and gene prediction

body_text.text: To estimate the mapping rate of the RNA sequences in the transcriptome [39] onto the MAC genome, we filtered the raw RNA-Seq reads using Trimmomatic (version 3.2.2) [31] and assembled them using rnaSPAdes (v3.14.0) [52] . We mapped the quality-filtered assembled RNA sequences onto the draft MAC genome using Bowtie2 (version 2.3.4.3) [53] and calculated the mapping rate as a percentage of the RNA sequences that were mapped onto the MAC genome over the total of RNA sequences. Conversely, we aligned some of the AUGUSTUSpredicted genes with the assembled RNA sequences using Bowtie2, with the default parameters and "very-sensitive-local option" applied, to assess the accuracy of the gene prediction. The mapping rate of MiSeq DNA reads onto the MAC genome was also calculated following the same procedure used for RNA sequences.
body_text.section: Evaluation of MAC genome completeness and gene prediction

body_text.text: To evaluate the scaffolds as complete chromosomes, we searched all the scaffolds for the presence of telomeric repeats using both SCAMPI [54] and etandem that is implemented in the EMBOSS (v2.5.0) [55] . We first searched the E. caudatum MAC genome for the telomeric repeats of T. thermophila (CCCCAACCCCAA [56] ), Paramecium spp. (CCC[C/A]AA [57] ), and Spirotrichea (CCCCAAAA [58] ) using the aforementioned tools and a custom Python script, but none were found. Using the custom Python script, we found (CCCCAAT)n at the ends of many scaffolds. We considered (CCCCAAT)n as the telomeric repeats of E. caudatum and thus searched all the scaffolds for its presence. The scaffolds with telomeric repeats capped at both ends (complete chromosomes) were also examined for the occurrence of subtelomeric regions (~100 bp) and their DNA sequence manually using a custom Python script. Only the scaffolds that had putative telomeric repeats (5'-CCCCAATCCCCAAT-3 ′ ; 3 ′ -GGGGATTGGGGATT-5 ′ ) at both ends were used examined. The number of genes and length distribution of the complete chromosomes were further analyzed.
body_text.section: Identification of telomeric repeats and subtelomeric regions

body_text.text: Codon usage was analyzed based on the protein-coding sequences using the CodonW package (version 1.4.4) against the universal codons (codonw.sourceforge.net/) and compared with those of the six other ciliate species. Percentage of the codons for lysine, glutamine, and glutamate that use G in position 3 (G3-KEQ), i.e. AAG, CAG, and GAG, respectively, relative to all the possible codons were calculated. The effective number of codons (Nc) was also computed. Both values were calculated based on the results of codon usage. The codon usage of the genomes of Fibrobacter succinogenes S85 (NC_017448.1), Prevotella ruminicola 23 (NC_014033.1), and Ruminococcus albus KH2T6 (NZ_FOAT01000001.1) were also computed, and their Nc, frequency of G3-KEQ, and AGA usage were compared to those of E. caudatum MAC genome.

We used Blast2GO to compute the overall statistics of MAC genome annotations [44, 45] . The protein-coding sequences of both the E. caudatum and six other ciliate species were taxonomically analyzed using the MG-RAST server [59] and the NCBI reference sequences [60] . A phylogenetic tree was constructed based on the 18S rRNA gene of E. caudatum predicted using RNAmmer (version 1.2) [49] and the 18S rRNA genes of the six ciliate species using MEGA6 with 1000 bootstraps [35] .

Protease-coding genes were predicted and identified using BLASTP against the MEROPS protease database (www.ebi.ac.uk/merops/, release 12.0). Putative proteases were determined at query coverage >80% and E-value <1e-10 and assigned to protease families based on the catalytic types of the most similar domains.

We identified the CAZymes from the protein sequences using the dbCAN2 meta server (bcb.unl.edu/dbCAN2/). Only the proteins that were successfully annotated by at least two of the three search tools (HMMER, E-value <1e-15, coverage >0. 35 ; DIAMOND, E-value <1e-102; and Hotpep, frequency > 2.6, hits >6) implemented in dbCAN2 were assumed to be CAZymes. The presence of a signal peptide was determined using the SignalP5.0 server (www.cbs.dtu.dk/services /SignalP/), and transmembrane helices were predicted using the TMHMM Server (v. 2.0) (www.cbs.dtu.dk/services/TMHMM/). To identify genes likely involved in symbiosis, we searched the UniProt annotations for the genes/gene products associated with GO:0018995 (host cellular component), GO:0033643 (host cell part), GO:0044110 (growth involved in symbiotic interaction), GO:0044216 (other organism cell), GO:0020005 (symbiont-containing vacuole membrane), GO:0044406 (adhesion of symbiont to host), GO:0044419 (interspecies interaction between organisms), and GO:1902579 (multi-organism localization).

Subcellular locations of the enzymes involved in anaerobic fermentation and the candidate proteins related to mitochondrion-related organelles (MROs), which were previously suggested from the transcriptome of Entodinium furca [61] , were predicted using MitoFates (http://mitf.cbrc.jp/MitoFates/cgi-bin/top.cgi) [62] and TargetP 2.0 [63] .
body_text.section: Localization of select proteins involved in fermentation and mitochondrion-related organelles

body_text.text: We screened the CAZymes for potentially horizontally transferred ones using ALIENNESS [64] . The ALIENNESS parameters were set as follows: taxonomic group of interest, Ciliophora; taxonomic group to exclude, Entodinium; taxonomic groups to classify potential donors, archaea, bacteria, fungi, and Ciliophora using their NCBI taxonomy ID. ALIENNESS detects HGT candidates based on Alien Index (AI) that was calculated as below: AI = log(best recipient E-value + e-200) -log(best donor E-value + e-200).

The CAZymes with an AI >30 and < 70% sequence identity to candidate donors were considered 'very likely' HGT candidates, and their taxonomy lineage were searched. Our previous RNA-seq data of E. caudatum [39] were used to confirm the expression of those HGT candidates by mapping their coding sequences to the mRNA assembly.

Following the steps in Supplementary Fig. S1 and Fig. 1 , after confirmation of the DNA extract by PCR amplification of the ciliate actin gene, we sequenced the MAC DNA first using two Illumina MiSeq runs. During the initial assembly of the MiSeq sequences, we noted that the MAC genome of E. caudatum probably had >10,000 chromosomes, which made the assembly challenging. We thus repeated the sequencing using the then newly available MinION and PacBio technologies. We performed hybrid assembly using the MiSeq sequences and the MinION sequences and then tribrid assembly using the sequences obtained from all the three technologies. The final tribrid assembly (referred to as draft MAC genome) yielded 12,348 scaffolds, with the N50 being 20,293 bp and the longest scaffold being 147,114 bp ( Table 1 ). The statistics of the scaffolds were shown in Supplementary Fig. S2 . Many thousands of scaffolds had putative telomeric repeats capped at one or both ends ( Supplementary Fig. S2C ). About 95.2% of the scaffolds met the criterion of nanochromosomes (0.4-40 kb in length) [65] , and 585 of the 619 scaffolds capped with telomere at both ends were nanochromosomes averaging 14.4 kb long. Based on the total scaffold length, the draft MAC genome was about 117 Mb, and the average coverage reached about 75 × .
body_text.section: Draft MAC genome of E. caudatum

body_text.text: We assessed the completeness of the draft MAC genome using four criteria: the number of core eukaryotic genes (CEGs) and the number of tRNA genes annotated, and the mapping rates of both the paired-end MiSeq reads and the transcriptomic sequences generated previously [39] . We found 239 of the 248 (96.37%) CEGs in total ( Supplementary  Table S2 ), with nine CEGs missing (Supplementary Table S3 ). Prediction of the tRNA genes using tRNAscan-SE found 143 tRNA genes coding for all the 20 standard amino acids and two tRNA genes coding for selenocysteine ( Supplementary Table S4 ). We finally assessed the completeness of the MAC genome by mapping the paired-end MiSeq reads and the RNA-seq sequences [39] using Bowtie2, and we achieved a mapping rate of 98.10% and 96.94%, respectively.
body_text.section: Draft MAC genome of E. caudatum

body_text.text: We did not find the telomeric repeats of T. thermophila, Paramecium spp. or Spirotrichea spp. in the draft MAC genome. Using custom Python scripts, we found 4514 of the scaffolds that were capped at one end, and another 619 were capped at both ends with (CCCCAAT)n and were assumed to be complete. These 'complete chromosomes' contains 4905 genes, and each of them carries on average 7.92 genes, with 62 carrying only one single gene. Within the 100-bp subtelomeric region (the region adjacent to the telomeric repeats) of the complete chromosomes, 15 AT periodicity was observed ( Supplementary Fig. S3 ). The GC content in this region was significantly lower (about 10.1%) than that of the predicted ORF sequences (about 23.7%).

The codon usage of the E. caudatum MAC genome, together with that of six model ciliates, is shown in Supplementary Table S5 and Fig. 2 . The preferred codons for lysine, glutamine, and arginine, were AAA, GAA, and AGA, respectively. The E. caudatum MAC genome had the lowest Nc (effective number of codons, which is a measure of the state of codon usage biases in genes and genomes [66] ), GC and G3-KEQ (G in position 3) content. The frequency of AGA for arginine was >70%, which is similar to that of O. trifallax. Compared to three major rumen bacterial species (i.e. Fibrobacter succinogenes, Prevotella ruminicola, and Ruminococcus albus), E. caudatum had a distinctly lower Nc and frequency of G3-KEQ but extremely high usage of AGA as the codon for arginine. The codon usage pattern of HGT candidates among the annotated CAZymes was similar to that of the overall E. caudatum MAC genome (Fig. 2) .

Gene prediction with AUGUSTUS achieved a 96.4% sensitivity and a 93.2% specificity at the exon level. The introns were short and considerably variable in length, with the majority being 30 to 60 nt and many being >200 nt ( Supplementary Fig. S2D ). A total of 45,974 Gene Ontology (GO) terms were annotated using Blast2GO. Among the protein-coding genes, there were 3833 hydrolases, 784 transferases, 125 isomerases, 90 oxidoreductases, 72 ligases, and 42 lyases; and 1281 protein-coding genes could be mapped to the KEGG metabolic pathways ( Supplementary Fig. S4 ). Among the 11 most represented metabolic pathways, carbohydrate metabolism and lipid metabolism were the first (36.69%) and the second (14.91%) most represented, respectively. The metabolic pathways identified from the MAC genome were also represented in the transcriptome of E. caudatum [39] ( Supplementary  Fig. S5 ).
body_text.section: Functional annotation of predicted protein-coding genes

body_text.text: 5144 genes were annotated to encode proteases, including metallo (42.48% of total), serine (28.11%), cysteine (19.38%), aspartic (6.30%), and threonine (2.94%) proteases ( Supplementary Table S6 ). Metallo proteases were the most enriched followed by serine and cysteine proteases among the ciliates included for comparison. Compared with the transcriptome of E. caudatum, the MAC genome had a lower frequency of metalloprotease but the opposite was true for the other four types of protease (Fig. 3 ).

We annotated 222 proteins as carbohydrate-active enzymes (CAZymes), which were assigned to 25 families of glycoside hydrolases (GH), 3 families of carbohydrate-binding modules (CBM), 2 families of carbohydrate esterases (CE), and 8 families of glycoside transferases (GT) (Fig. 4) . Among the GH families, those involved in the utilization of starch (i.e. GH13 and GH31), hemicellulose (i.e. GH43 and GH53), galactoside or raffinose (i.e. GH2 and GH30), and mannan and mannose (e.g. GH38) were enriched. Some GH families (i.e. GH18, GH24, GH84, and GH89) were annotated as lysozyme and chitinase. These putative lysozymes and chitinases were further validated by annotations using the Clusters of Orthologous Groups of proteins (COGs), UniProt, and Pfam (protein families) database (Supplementary Table S7 ). The expression of most of the GHs was also confirmed in the E. caudatum transcriptome ( Supplementary Table S8 ), but seven GHs and several other CAZymes were not found in the transcriptome ( Supplementary  Table S9 ). Several GTs (i.e. GT5 and GT35) were annotated to participate in the synthesis of glycogen, the storage carbohydrate in E. caudatum. The predicted CBMs were mainly associated with starch binding.

Some of the enzymes were predicted to be involved in volatile fatty acid (VFA) production and were mapped to the fermentation pathways of acetate, butyrate, lactate, and succinate, but not propionate (Supplementary Table S10 and Supplementary Fig. S4 ). The butyrate fermentation pathway had all the enzymes represented except for β-hydroxybutyryl-CoA dehydrogenase, crotonyl-CoA reductase, and butyrate kinase based on the KEGG ortholog annotation, or the COG and Swiss-Prot database even with a less strict bit-score or E-value cutoff (data not shown). No enzyme was mapped to the acrylate pathway of propionate production, but lactate dehydrogenase and fumarate reductase was found in both the MAC genome and the transcriptome. Iron hydrogenases were found. All the enzymes involved in anaerobic fermentation including hydrogenase were predicted to be located in the cytoplasm by MitoFates and TargetP 2.0.
body_text.section: Enzymes driving volatile fatty acid production

body_text.text: Oxygen-scavenging enzymes, including superoxide dismutase (SOD), glutathione peroxidase (GPx), and peroxiredoxin were found in the E. caudatum MAC genome (Supplementary Table S11 ). All these enzymes had an Alien Index (AI) of zero, and their best BLASTP matches were all bacterial.

Searching the UniProt annotations for the GO terms involved in symbiosis, which had been previously described in the E. caudatum transcriptome [39] , we detected eight GO terms involved in symbiosis, including symbiont-containing vacuole membrane (GO:0020005), growth involved in symbiotic interaction (GO:0044110), other organism cells (GO:0044216), adhesion of symbiont to host (GO:0044406), interspecies interaction between organisms (GO:0044419), and multiorganism localization (GO:1902579) ( Supplementary Table S12 ).

Signaling pathways were identified by annotation using the KEGG pathway database. In total, 39 signal transduction-related pathways were found (Supplementary Table S13 ), and all were also represented in the transcriptome of E. caudatum [39] . More proteins were identified in the MAC genome than in the transcriptome for most of the signaling pathways.

We examined the scaffolds for rRNA genes using RNAmmer and Rfam. One scaffold (referred to as Ento_MGS_500) contained one complete operon of rRNA genes with a typical organization ( Supplementary  Fig. S6 ). The 18S rRNA gene had a 99.69% sequence identity with that of E. caudatum already in NCBI (accession number: AM158446.1). The NCBI database contains no 28S or 5.8S rRNA gene of E. caudatum, and thus comparison could not be made.

Using ALIENNESS and AI>30 and protein sequence identity <70% with the protein sequences from "donor" as the criteria for 'very likely HGT' candidates [67] , we predict the CAZyme genes likely acquired through horizontal gene transfer (HGT). We focused on CAZyme genes because they enable E. caudatum to acquire the ability to utilize polysaccharides and contribute to feed degradation. Of the 26 GH families detected, 20 contained varying numbers of very likely HGT candidates, and most of them were predicted to have a bacterial origin, mostly species of the phylum Firmicutes ( Table 2 ). All the proteins annotated to GH5, GH16, GH18, GH24, GH26, GH30, GH43, GH77, GH84, GH89, GH93, and GH163 were very likely HGT candidates. About half of the very likely HGT candidates had a predicted signal peptide. Ten of the 17 very likely HGT candidates in GH3 were predicted to be transferred from the fungal genus Neocallimastix. All the very likely HGT candidates were also detected in the transcriptome [39] .
body_text.section: Genes likely acquired through horizontal gene transfer

body_text.text: We compared the MAC genome of E. caudatum with that of six other species of ciliates. The E. caudatum MAC genome is the largest in size and number of predicted protein-coding genes ( Supplementary Table S1 ). As with the three ciliate species of the class Spirotrichea, the MAC genome of E. caudatum (class Litostomatea) also had many nanochromosomes. The predicted orthologs of the E. caudatum MAC genome had the most hits with those of the MAC genomes of the eight ciliate species, one fungal species, and one bacterial species, O. trifallax having the most shared orthologs (Fig. 5A) . The E. caudatum MAC genome also had more protein sequences predicted to be of archaeal or bacterial origin than the other six ciliate species (Fig. 5B) , and 946 sequences were aligned to the sequences of an uncultured Proteobacteria bacterium TMED154.
body_text.section: Comparison of the MAC genomes and predicted orthologs between E. caudatum and other ciliates

body_text.text: We searched the E. caudatum MAC genome for the presence of the mitochondrial transfer peptide or pre-sequences that were suggested as MROs candidates of E. furca transcriptome, but no clear evidence for the Table S14 ).

Unlike aerobic free-living ciliates, including the important model species T. thermophila, P. tetraurelia, O. trifallax, anaerobic symbiotic ciliates, including the common ciliates residing in the rumen, are notably understudied and poorly understood. As the second-largest group of the rumen microbiome, rumen protozoa play important role in the digestion and fermentation of feed, determining the efficiency of dietary nitrogen utilization, and the output of wastes as nitrogen and methane. These roles are determined by their metabolism and interactions with the other members of the rumen microbiome, via predation and symbiosis. The lack of axenic cultures of any rumen protozoan has limited the understanding of the fundamental biological features of rumen protozoa. The draft MAC genome of E. caudatum thus provided the first genomic insights into the biological features that make these protozoa particularly adapted to the rumen environment.

The MAC genomes (all draft) of about a dozen free-living ciliates have been sequenced, and they are species the classes Spirotrichea (4 species), Oligohymenophorea (7 species), or Heterotrichea (1 species). The MAC genome structure of N. ovalis, a ciliate living in the hindgut of cockroaches, has been studied but not sequenced [22] . The MAC genomes of the species of Spirotrichea, Nassophorea, and Phyllopharyngea are unique in that they contain a large number of nanochromosomes that are short DNA fragments generated during the formation of the MAC from the MIC [26, 65] . Like the ciliates in these three classes, Table 2 CAZymes genes a in the E. caudatum MAC genome that were putatively acquired through horizontal gene transfers. Only intronless and very likely HGT candidates (Alien Index >30) were presented. All the very likely HGT candidates were successfully mapped to the RNA-seq assemblies. a Annotated to be CAZyme genes by at least two of the three tools (Hmmer, Diamond, and Hotpep) of dbCAN2. b Number of HGT candidates with an Alien Index >30.

E. caudatum also has a MAC genome that contains a very large number of nanochromosomes, which created assembly challenges because of the fragmented architecture and nonuniform nanochromosome copy number [21] . The tribrid assembly approach allowed for a draft MAC genome. This approach may be used in sequencing the MAC genomes of other ciliates, especially those that contain many thousands of chromosomes.

The draft E. caudatum MAC genome (~117 Mb) was among the largest of the sequenced ciliate species. The finding of 96.4% of the "universal" CEGs, tRNA genes for all the amino acids, telomeric repeats aping about half of the scaffolds (>600 capped at both ends), and high mapping rates of both DNA (>98%) and RNA (>96%) sequencing reads, the E. caudatum MAC genomes was probably approaching its completeness. It is worth noting that the almost completed MAC genomes of other ciliates, such as T. thermophila and O. trifallax, do not contain all the 245 ciliate-specific CEGs [26] . Among the three "universal" CEGs missing in the other ciliate species, we found 6-phosphogluconolactonase (KOG3147) and 6-phosphogluconate dehydrogenase (KOG2653) but not glucose-6-phosphate 1-dehydrogenase (G6PD, KOG0563). The lack of G6PD is consistent with the enzymological evidence that isotrichids rumen protozoa only used the Embden-Meyerhof-Parnas pathway [3] . Another CEG that is missing in the E. caudatum MAC genome encodes cytochrome c1 (KOG3052). This protein was not found in Dasytricha [68] , and its absence in the E. caudatum MAC genome is consistent with the anaerobiotic ecology of rumen protozoa.

The telomere sequences of E. caudatum were unknown. Capping 4514 scaffolds at one end and another 619 at both ends, (CCCCAAT)n is probably the telomeric repeat of E. caudatum chromosomes. This telomeric sequence differs from that of other ciliate species. E. caudatum, which is a species in the class Litostomatea, probably has a different telomere sequence. Additionally, subtelomeric regions, which form the DNA loops and backbone of the unique chromosomal structure, rosettes [12, 69] , were found adjacent to the telomeric repeats of many E. caudatum chromosomes. As in other ciliate species, the subtelomeric regions have distinct AT periodicity and low GC content. The low GC content (~10%) in the subtelomeric region of E. caudatum chromosomes was similar to that of O. trifallax and Sty. lemnae [21, 26] , but the G or C periodicity which was found in O. trifallax and Sty. lemnae, was not found in E. caudatum. The finding of the characteristic of subtelomeric regions suggests that the newly found (CCCCAAT)n is probably the telomeric repeats of E. caudatum chromosomes and a high degree of completeness of the E. caudatum chromosomes. It should be noted that telomeres are difficult to sequence because they are located at the chromosome ends, where overlapping is much less likely than in the other region of a chromosome, and have repetitive sequences. The combination of telomere-primer PCR amplification and high-throughput sequencing [41] may be used to sequence the missing telomeres and help complete the E. caudatum chromosomes. The putative telomeric repeats (CCCCAAT)n can be used to design the telomere PCR primers.

Consistent with its extremely low GC content (~23%), the E. caudatum protein-coding genes have a low frequency of G3-KEQ and preference of AGA as the codon for arginine. These two bias patterns have been reported in the cloned DNA of E. caudatum and two other species of the Ophryoscolecidae family (i.e. Epidinium spp., and Polyplastron multivesiculatum) [43, 70] . Most rumen bacteria and archaea have the opposite codon usage biases, probably because of their high GC content (>40%) of their genomes [70] . The low Nc value and G3-KEQ frequency compared to those of rumen bacteria and other ciliates [70] indicate unbalanced usage of universal codons in the E. caudatum MAC genome. The frequencies of UAA and UAG were relatively lower in the E. caudatum MAC genome than in the MAC genomes of other ciliates (data not shown), and those two codons were thought to be used as stop codons by E. caudatum [71] .

Rumen protozoa have abundant sources of polysaccharides (primarily dietary) and protein (both dietary and microbial) as their substrates. Conceivably, the E. caudatum MAC genome is enriched with GHs and peptidases. Among the annotated GHs, GH13 (particularly α-amylases) was the most enriched in both the MAC genome and the transcriptome [39] of E. caudatum, followed by GH31 (mostly α-glucosidases). These findings corroborate starch being the primary substrate for the growth and synthesis of reserve carbohydrates in E. caudatum [3] [72] . Responsible for galactoside utilization, GH2 was also found in both the MAC genome and transcriptome. Galactosidase in rumen ciliates [73] help degrade the ingested chloroplasts and utilize the released polyunsaturated fatty acids [74, 75] . Families of GH and CE related to hemicellulose utilization (e.g. GH43, GH53, CE1, and CE2) were found in the MAC genome of E. caudatum, but they were not highly expressed in the transcriptome. Three cellulase genes (in GH5) were found in the MAC genome, but they were barely expressed [39] . The genomic and transcriptomic data corroborate the inability of Entodinium spp. to utilize cellulose [3, 76] and the very weak xylanase and endoglucanase activities of the cell-free extract of Entodinium spp. [77] .
body_text.section: Substrate spectrum, predicted fermentation pathways, and the subcellular localization of related enzymes

body_text.text: Rumen protozoa are blamed for lowering dietary NUE in ruminants. Entodinium is recognized as the main culprit [7] , and E. caudatum is the most bacterivorous species [5, 6] . Besides bacteria, rumen protozoa prey on rumen fungi also [78] . Conceivably, genes encoding lysozyme, chitinase, and N-acetylglucosaminidase were found in the E. caudatum MAC genome. These cell wall-degrading enzymes were highly expressed in the transcriptome of E. caudatum [39] . Two recent studies have shown that inhibition of lysozyme decreased the growth of E. caudatum and other rumen protozoa and lower ammonia-N production [79, 80] . The sequences of the lysozyme can be used to develop specific inhibitors to effectively and specifically inhibit rumen protozoa, at least Entodinium spp., to improve dietary NUE in ruminants.
body_text.section: Substrate spectrum, predicted fermentation pathways, and the subcellular localization of related enzymes

body_text.text: Pyruvate:ferredoxin oxidoreductase (PFOR) was found in the E. caudatum MAC genome, but not pyruvate formate lyase or pyruvate dehydrogenase complex, indicating that E. caudatum uses PFOR to activate pyruvate for further metabolism. The fermentation products of E. caudatum and their relative profiles are not well defined. Based on the genes we found in both the MAC genome and the transcriptome, E. caudatum should be able to produce acetate, lactate, succinate, H 2, and CO 2 . Besides, butyrate is probably also a fermentation product because all the genes of the butyrate fermentation pathways were found in the MAC genome and the transcriptome together (not in the MAC genome or the transcriptome alone). E. caudatum probably does not produce propionate as its fermentation pathway was not represented by any of the genes. The propionate found in the E. caudatum culture by Abmu Akkada et al. [81] might be produced by contaminating bacteria. Acetate is the major fermentation product, and genes coding both phosphotransacetylase and acetate kinase, both of which can convert acetyl-CA to acetate, were found. Biochemical analysis can help verify if E. caudatum uses both enzymes for acetate production.
body_text.section: Substrate spectrum, predicted fermentation pathways, and the subcellular localization of related enzymes

body_text.text: Many of the mitochondrial or hydrogenosomal enzymes found in other ciliates (e.g. malate dehydrogenase or hydrogenase) were not predicted to be mitochondrial in the E. caudatum MAC genome, suggesting that E. caudatum lacks hydrogenosomes. This is consistent with the previous reports [82, 83] . The predicted subcellular localization of enzymes related to anaerobic fermentation also indicates that E. caudatum probably relies on cytosolic ATP production as other eukaryotes containing mitosomes do, such as species of Giardia and Entamoeba [84, 85] . Mitosomes, instead of hydrogenosomes, were suggested as MROs for some rumen entodiniomorphs including E. caudatum [86] . Mitosomes constitute one of the four types of MROs (together with hydrogenosomes, anaerobic mitochondria, and hydrogen-producing mitochondria) found in eukaryotes living under low-oxygen conditions. Although known to lack the ability to produce ATP or hydrogen and play a role in iron-sulfur metabolism [87, 88] , little is known about this type of mitochondrial remnants. Our MAC genomic data did not confirm the presence of mitosomes in E. caudatum. Future research using other technologies is needed to verify the specific types of MROs present in E. caudatum.
body_text.section: Substrate spectrum, predicted fermentation pathways, and the subcellular localization of related enzymes

body_text.text: When compared with the predicted proteomes of other ciliate species, the predicted proteome of E. caudatum had the most hits with that of O. trifallax. Additionally, 2.28% of the E. caudatum proteome matched the proteins of ruminal ciliates (reported in E. caudatum, Eudiplodinium maggii, Metadinium medium, Isotricha spp., Pol. multivesiculatum) that were archived in the NCBI NR database. The majority (89.33%) of the annotated E. caudatum proteome were expressed in the transcriptome of E. caudatum [39] , strongly suggesting a high accuracy of the gene prediction. This also suggests that most of the genes are expressed in E. caudatum during typical growth.

E. caudatum was known to be the most bacterivorous species in the rumen [5] and has the highest rate of proteolysis compared to the other rumen ciliates [89] . As expected, the E. caudatum MAC genome encodes a large repertoire (a total of 110 families) of peptidases, which reached 8.74% of the E. caudatum proteome and was higher than that of the freeliving ciliates including Euplotes vannus (3.30%), O. trifallax (6.41%), and Sty. lemnae (6.97%). Of the top four families (i.e. aspartic, cysteine, metallo, and serine peptidases, accounting for 96.27% of the total), metallopeptidases were the most prevalent in the MAC genome, but in the transcriptome cysteine and serine proteases were more highly expressed [39] . The rich representation of those peptidases, along with the lysozyme and N-acetylglucosaminidase, mirrors the high density of prokaryotes (primarily bacteria) surrounding rumen protozoa and corroborates the high bacterivory and proteolysis of E. caudatum. Some of the amino acids released from the degradation of microbial protein can be used by protozoa [2] , but more is excreted and deaminated by rumen bacteria [90] , a wasteful process in terms of dietary nitrogen utilization in ruminants. We recently showed that inhibitors of cysteine and serine peptidases dramatically inhibited E. caudatum and other rumen protozoa and decreased ammoniagenesis in vitro [79, 80] . The genomic sequences of the identified peptidases can be used to design inhibitors specific to E. caudatum to effectively inhibit the most bacterivorous Entodinium species in the rumen.

Many genes of the E. caudatum MAC genome were taxonomically classified as bacterial (about 15.8% of all the protein-coding genes) and archaea (1.1%), and those genes were likely acquired through HGT. Contamination could not be ruled out, but it was probably minimal because of the isolation and purification procedures we used. Additionally, all the HGT candidates were mapped to the transcriptome. Gene acquisition through HGT was about 4% of the 4300 expressed sequence tags (EST) in rumen protozoa [1] . Protozoa are especially amenable to HGT, because of the endosymbiotic relationship with prokaryotes [91, 92] and the presence of dense bacterial and archaeal populations in the rumen. Unfortunately, the symbionts of E. caudatum is not known [93] . The high HGT candidate frequency in the E. caudatum MAC genome may also be attributable to its high bacterivory and high likelihood to incorporate prokaryotic DNA into their genome, especially during the MAC development after conjugation [94] . It is worth noting that many of the putative HGT candidates were annotated as GHs of major carbohydrates in the rumen including, starch, hemicellulose, and even lysozyme and chitinase. This is in general agreement with the ESTs study on rumen protozoa [1] . Being able to acquire GHs from other microbes would allow E. caudatum to be competitive in the carbohydrate-rich rumen environment.
body_text.section: Candidate genes acquired through horizontal gene transfers

body_text.text: Rumen protozoa are thought to help create anaerobiosis by consuming the O 2 entering the rumen, which benefits other strictly anaerobic microorganisms [95, 96] . Using washed cells and inhibitors of respiration, Yarlett et al. showed that Dasytricha ruminantium, a rumen isotrichid, could respire in its hydrogenosomes using free O 2 [97] . However, activity-based enzyme assays failed to detect SOD, an enzyme essential for quenching reactive O 2 species (ROS) in D. ruminantium and other protozoal species [68, 98] . The finding of genes encoding ROSquenching enzymes (i.e. SOD, GPx, and peroxiredoxin), but not the proteins or enzymes of electron transport, in both the MAC genome and transcriptome indicates that E. caudatum cannot respirate using O 2 as a terminal electron acceptor, but it can tolerate O 2 . Transcripts encoding SOD and GPx were also detected in E. furca, Diplodinium dentatum, Isotricha intestinalis [61] . For anaerobic ciliates, the presence of SOD is critical for their aerotolerance [99, 100] . Indeed, we noted that E. caudatum could survive intermittent O 2 exposure for up to h of incubation in a previous study [101] .

Protozoa can respond and adapt to changes in internal and external environments by altering their metabolic processes and other physiological behaviors such as the movement of cilia and chemotaxis. The many signaling pathways represented in the MAC genome and the transcriptome [39] corroborate the above capability. Notably, signaling pathways involving receptor tyrosine kinase (RTK), such as calcium/ calmodulin and MAPK signaling pathways, both of which regulate ciliary movement, cell growth, and other functions by activating the pellicle-bound guanylate cyclase [102] , had been previously demonstrated to be essential for chemotaxis in E. caudatum [103] . The signaling pathways enable E. caudatum to cope with the nutritional and environmental fluctuations in the rumen. Several studies showed probably endosymbionts especially methanogens in E. caudatum [28, [104] [105] [106] . However, transmission electron microscopy showed only very few bacteria inside of washed E. caudatum cells [14] , and endosymbiotic methanogens were not found [28] . It is unknown if E. caudatum has permanent specific endosymbionts, but the absolute requirement for mixed live rumen bacteria [14] suggests such a possibility. The E. caudatum MAC genome eight GO terms involved in symbiosis, including "adhesion of symbiont to host", "symbiont-containing vacuole membrane", "interspecies interaction between organisms", and cytosolic NLRC5, the last of which is involved in interspecies interaction and might be linked to the innate recognition by rumen ciliates for extraand intracellular bacteria [107, 108] . These genomic and transcriptomic results suggest the presence of endosymbionts inside E. caudatum cells. Identification and understanding of the endosymbionts can help characterize E. caudatum and other rumen ciliates with respect to their distinct biological features.

Collectively, a combination of the next-and third-generation sequencing technologies and tribrid assembly enabled us to sequence the metabolically active MAC genome of E. caudatum MZG-1. Although not complete, the draft MAC genome captured most of the genes. Like species in the class Litostomatea, E. caudatum MAC genome-like species of the classes Phyllopharyngea, Spirotrichea, and Armophorea, E. caudatum has numerous nanochromosomes. New telomeric repeats capped nearly half of the chromosomes at one or both ends. The MAC genome provided genetic evidence on the substrate spectrum, fermentation pathways and products, and enzymes that reflect its high bacterivory. A myriad of CAZyme genes was probably acquired from rumen bacteria through HGT. Other biological features, such as symbiosis, quenching of ROS, and signal transduction to respond to external stimuli, were also revealed. The current results will enable future biochemical characterization of some of the proteins and enzymes and understand the biological features of E. caudatum. The MAC genome of E. caudatum can help future genomic and transcriptomic studies of other rumen protozoa. Some of the genes can serve as the targets to develop specific inhibitors to control rumen protozoa to improve NUE and reduce methane emissions from ruminants.

T.Park et al.

FIGREF0.text: Major steps of MAC separation, genome sequencing, and bioinformatic analysis of E. caudatum MAC genome. (A) schematic diagram of the major steps for MAC genome analysis, (B) scanned electron micrograph of E. caudatum (C), isolated MAC stained with methyl green, and (D) amplification of ciliate actin gene. The scale bars = 10 μm. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)

FIGREF1.text: Codon usage of the MAC genome and HGT candidates of the CAZymes of E. caudatum. CodonW was used to calculate the relative frequency of each codon based on the universal genetic code. The relative frequency of G3-KEQ and AGA was also added.

FIGREF2.text: Relative frequency of the protease families in the MAC genome and the transcriptome of E. caudatum. Only the five major proteases families were shown.

FIGREF3.text: Enzymes annotated as glycoside hydrolases (A) and other carbohydrate-active enzymes (CAZymes) (B).T.Park et al.

FIGREF4.text: Taxonomic distribution of the annotated proteome of E. caudatum. The top 10 species of microbes that had the most Blast hits (A) and the taxonomic distribution of the annotated proteome of E. caudatum and six other species of ciliates (B). Protein-coding sequences were used as the representative sequences for each ciliate for taxonomic classification at domain level using RefSeq run through MG-RAST. The phylogeny based on the 18S rRNA genes of seven ciliate species.
